activity.name: Satisfy capability demand using engineered system
activity.description: Bring together organizations to form an extended enterprise to create, operate and dispose of a system that provides a specified capability.

activity.name: Satisfy capability demand using engineered system
activity.description: Bring together organizations to form an extended enterprise to create, operate and dispose of a system that provides a specified capability.

activity.name: Establish enterprise agreement
activity.description: Achieve an agreement between two organizations, one in the role of acquirer and the other as supplier so as to effect the provision of a product or service.

activity.name: Manage enterprise
activity.description: Establish, operate and maintain the enterprise as the framework by which to initiate, support and monitor projects.

activity.name: Manage project
activity.description: Perform proper planning and control of a project and project-wide factors . Note: The project-wide factors are risk, configuration and management

activity.name: Execute project
activity.description: Perform the technical processes that mark the successive stages of the system life cycle.

activity.name: Plan, assess and control project
activity.description: Establish and evolve project plans, assess actual achievement and progress against the plans and control execution of the project through to fulfilment.

activity.name: Make decision
activity.description: Select the most beneficial course of project action where alternatives exist. Note: Project feedback provides the information by which to recognize the existence of problems and opportunities that lead to a requirement for project decisions.

activity.name: Manage risk, configuration and information
activity.description: Minimize the effects of uncertain events, establish and maintain the integrity of all products of a project and provide relevant, timely, complete valid, confidential information to both the enterprise and external parties.

activity.name: Define system
activity.description: Create specifications at successive tiers of the system right down to individual components.

activity.name: Produce system
activity.description: Realize and test successive tiers of the system in accordance with the applicable specification.

activity.name: Validate produced system
activity.description: Provide objective evidence that the capabilities provided by the system when in use comply with the requirements of the relevant stakeholders.

activity.name: Exploit system
activity.description: Operate, maintain and dispose of the system so as to fulfil the demands on the system capability for the agreed service life of the system.

activity.name: Control engineering change
activity.description: Analyze technical impact of discovered issues and generate feedback to initiate project control processes to assess cost, risk and schedule impacts. Note: change proposal * is the basis for activation of Manage project to look at non-technical project issues such as cost, risk and schedule.

activity.name: Create systems engineering model
activity.description: Develop a model at each tier of the system as the basis for a structured set of specifications.

activity.name: Design system component
activity.description: Create a design specification that provides sufficient detail to enable production and testing of a component.

activity.name: Create model for domain tier
activity.description: Perform the generic systems engineering modelling process to generate a specification that can serve across multiple customer organizations in the domain. Example: This modelling creates a problem description that will possibly result in more than one separately purchased, interacting system, such as in examining the domain of air transport, where aircraft interact with air traffic control systems and airports.

activity.name: Create model for concept tier
activity.description: Perform the generic systems engineering modelling process to generate a specification to address requirements in a customer organization. Note: This modelling creates what is often known as the user or stakeholder requirement (context view) and the system requirement (subject view). These requirements can be in the form of a user requirement document (URD) and a system requirement document (SRD).

activity.name: Create model for system tier
activity.description: Perform the generic systems engineering modelling process to provide a specification to address the concept tier model set as a source of requirements. Note: This modelling creates what is often known as the architectural design.

activity.name: Create model for sub-system tier
activity.description: Perform the generic systems engineering modelling process to provide a specification to address requirements from a partition of the system or higher level sub-system tier.

activity.name: Create model for component tier
activity.description: Perform the generic systems engineering modelling process to provide a specification to address requirements from an atomic partition of a system or sub-system tier model.

activity.name: Analyze context
activity.description: Perform the generic process to create a model set and, thus, address the context for the subject within the applicable tier of the system.

activity.name: Analyze subject
activity.description: Perform the generic process to create a model set and, thus, address the subject within the applicable tier of the system.

activity.name: Assess available information
activity.description: Prepare foundational information that is necessary for systems engineering modelling. Note: This information can include: text requirements; heritage information; user information; operations concepts as text; and initial models.

activity.name: Build solution model
activity.description: Identify effectiveness measures as the basis for trade-off and create both behaviour and structure models

activity.name: Perform trade-off analysis
activity.description: Choose among alternative solutions within the models.

activity.name: Create plan for build and test
activity.description: Address both management of technical issues to establish a schedule that is feasible for production of a solution to the specification models.

activity.name: Define effectiveness measure
activity.description: Establish the criteria by which alternative model specifications will be judged.

activity.name: Create behaviour model
activity.description: Define either the excitations or responses for the subject at the system tier of interest.

activity.name: Create structure model
activity.description: Identify the logical and physical composition for the specification.

activity.name: Accept model information
activity.description: Confirm the availability and status of all information necessary for conducting trade-off analysis.

activity.name: Determine attribute value
Calculate system performance
activity.description: Use obtained attribute values to determine the overall system performance in terms of the applicable set of requirements.

activity.name: Compare effectiveness of feasible solutions
activity.description: Rank all feasible solutions on the basis of applicable effectiveness measures and determine the optimum solution.

activity.name: Produce system component
activity.description: Realize and test a component of the system in accordance with the applicable design.

activity.name: Integrate component into system
activity.description: Take component and install in the applicable location within the system.

activity.name: Verify system
activity.description: Demonstrate that the characteristics and behaviour of a system or system element comply with the applicable architectural design specification

activity.name: Install system
activity.description: Take verified system and install in operational environment.

icom.name: agreement
icom.description: Mutual acknowledgement of terms and conditions under which to conduct a working relationship.

icom.name: agreement feedback
icom.description: Feedback that conveys results of activities across an enterprise back to applicable agreement processes.

icom.name: attribute value
icom.description: Value that indicates a specific characteristic of the system corresponding to a proposed system model.

icom.name: authorized engineering change
icom.description: Change that has received approval for application to one or more technical elements in the creation or operation of a system. Note: Technical elements can include systems engineering models, design specifications, system or system elements.

icom.name: authorized project action
icom.description: Action that is allowable on the basis of an approval in accordance with defined authorities for a project.

icom.name: behaviour model
icom.description: Model that represents all functions of the context or subject at a tier of a system and the ordering, inputs and outputs of those functions.

icom.name: by-product
icom.description: Item that arises during production, operation or maintenance of a system and no longer has a useful role to play in the life cycle of the system.

icom.name: change proposal
icom.description: Proposal that identifies the characteristics of a change to some technical element in the creation, operation, maintenance or disposal of a system. Note: A project team will consider the non-technical implications of a change proposal before authorizing the change to become a reality. The extent and formality of this consideration will depend on the expected impact of the change (in general, impact increases with time during the system life cycle). Organization, enterprise or project policy will specify the criteria on which to assess a change proposal.

icom.name: chosen solution
icom.description: Model information that is an optimal specification for a system. Note: The effectivess measures are the basis for choosing this one solution over other feasible alternatives.

icom.name: component for integration
icom.description: Component that is ready for integration into an emerging system.

icom.name: component tier model
icom.description: Set that consists of both the context and subject models specifying a component within a system.

icom.name: concept tier model
icom.description: Developed model set that consists of both the context and subject models specifying the concept tier view of a system.

icom.name: context model set
icom.description: Set that consists of a behaviour model, structure model and implementation plan for the context of a subject within a tier of a system.

icom.name: demand on system capability
icom.description: Change that occurs to the operational environment of a system and initiates a response from the system.

icom.name: design for system component
icom.description: Specification that provides sufficient descriptive detail to enable the production and testing of a component so as to meet user requirements during operation, maintenance and disposal processes.

icom.name: developed model set
effectiveness measure
icom.description: Requirement that is so important as to have a critical impact on the success or failure of a system. Example: When engineering a laptop computer, two major effectiveness measures (optimization criteria) are typically mass and battery life. The engineer will attempt to minimize mass and maximize battery life.

icom.name: enabling system
icom.description: System that complements the system-of-interest for the purposes of one or more life-cycle processes. Note: For example, a production enabling system is necessary in order to manufacture and integrate the system. Each enabling system has a distinct life cycle.

icom.name: enterprise
icom.description: Virtual organization that is the result of one or more agreements between two or more organizations and is responsible for the life cycle of a system.

icom.name: enterprise feedback
icom.description: Feedback that conveys the results of project activities to the wider enterprise.

icom.name: enterprise policy or procedure
icom.description: Control that is the basis on which to conduct technical or managerial activity for projects within an enterprise. Note: An enterprise policy or procedure is complementary to all relevant organization policies or procedures or social, legal or political directives.

icom.name: existing system or element
icom.description: Item that is available from another enterprise for re-use in another system.

icom.name: feasible solution
icom.description: Model information that specifies a solution meeting the applicable requirements.

icom.name: implementation plan
icom.description: Plan that specifies the order for the build and test of a tier of a system.

icom.name: information from external source
icom.description: Information that arises from any source outside the system enterprise.

icom.name: initial model set
icom.description: Model information that is available when beginning the systems engineering modelling process. Note: In general, the systems engineering modelling process is flexible. Such modelling can be top-down, bottom-up, out-in or middle-out in terms of the sequence of tiers. For simple systems, the difference between the tiers requires a minimum amount of formal project control and an individual engineer can work at more than one tier in parallel.

icom.name: ISO 15288
icom.description: Systems engineering -- System life cycle processes.

icom.name: ISO 9001
icom.description: Quality management systems -- Requirements.

icom.name: map of _functions
icom.description: Set of relationships that each identify the correspondence between a structural element and a behaviour.

icom.name: model set
icom.description: Information that consists of all proposed systems engineering models for a particular tier of a system.

icom.name: modelling database
icom.description: Information that consists of all in-work systems engineering models to date for a system.

icom.name: multi-project management aid
icom.description: Aid that is available to more than one project within an enterprise and able to support common approaches to management across the enterprise.

icom.name: organization
icom.description: Business entity that consists of an interacting collection of personnel, infrastructure and facilities. Note: For example, an organization can be: - a company; - a government department.

icom.name: organization policy or procedure
icom.description: Control that a member organization of a system enterprise applies to business activities and requires the enterprise to take account of. Note: An organization policy or procedure is complementary to all relevant social, legal or political directives.X

icom.name: other standard
icom.description: Standard that is neither ISO 9001 nor ISO 15288 and is available from a statutory standards organization. Example: The following other standards are relevant to systems engineering: - EIA 632 "Processes for engineering a system"; - IEEE 1220 "Standard for application and management of the systems engineering process".

icom.name: project decision
icom.description: Choice that establishes the optimum project action against a given set of criteria.

icom.name: project definition
project feedback
icom.description: Feedback that conveys the results of technical activities in a project to the managers of the project.

icom.name: project policy or procedure
icom.description: Control that is the basis on which to conduct technical processes within a project. Note: A project policy or procedure is complementary to all relevant enterprise or organization policies or procedures or social, legal or political directives.

icom.name: raw material or consumable
icom.description: Item that manufacturing processes will transform to become an integral part of a system.

icom.name: realized system or sub-system
icom.description: System or sub-system that is complete and is ready for verification testing.

icom.name: recycled raw material
icom.description: Item that was once either a part of a system or necessary to operate, maintain or dispose of a system and is ready to be raw material in some further process.

icom.name: register of risk
icom.description: Information that identifies and defines risks that are applicable to a project.

icom.name: rejected system or element
icom.description: Item that has not met applicable test criteria and requires either corrective action or disposal.

icom.name: requirements database
satisfied demand on system capability
icom.description: Change that occurs to the operational environment of a system as the result of operation of the system.

icom.name: set of component requirements
icom.description: Set that consists of both the behaviour and the structure model for a component within a system.

icom.name: social legal or political directive
icom.description: Directive that is beyond the direct control of a system enterprise or constituent organizations.

icom.name: society or organization feedback
icom.description: Feedback that connects an enterprise to the broader industrial and social context. Note: This feedback can include: - responses to requirements to provide information either to a member organization of an enterprise or to some other external party; - requests for information from parties external to an enterprise.

icom.name: specification for existing system or element
icom.description: Specification that defines the characteristics of an item that is available from another enterprise.

icom.name: structure model
icom.description: Model that represents the static structure of the context or subject at a tier of a system. Note: A structure model is not the same as a structural analysis model that indicates the stress-strain response to a load for a mechanical system or physical component.

icom.name: sub-system for integration
icom.description: Sub-system that is ready for integration into an emerging system.

icom.name: system assurance evidence
icom.description: Evidence that supports and validates the predictions of system performance and safety and is the basis on which the acquirer can accept the system as meeting the terms of the applicable enterprise agreement.

icom.name: system for installation
icom.description: System that is verified as complete and is ready for installation in the operational environment.

icom.name: system for validation
icom.description: System that is installed in the operational environment and is ready for validation testing.

icom.name: system or element for re-use
icom.description: Item that is the result of systems engineering and ready for re-use in a system of another enterprise.

icom.name: system ready for exploitation
icom.description: System that is validated and is ready for operation.

icom.name: technical issue
icom.description: Issue that relates to some technical element in the creation, operation, maintenance or disposal of a system.

icom.name: trade-off result
icom.description: Result that indicates the basis on which individual potential system or system element solutions meet or fail to satisfy the identified effectiveness measures.

icom.name: transfer of system responsibility
icom.description: Notification that indicates a successful installation of a system in the operational environment and passes responsibility for the system to the intended operator.

icom.name: waste material
icom.description: Item that is in a condition beyond serviceable use.
